This is probably wrong as it assumes the "mon host" part of the dcnX.conf will be populated by this value: double check

To clarify... 

dcn0 should have it's own mon, not it's own mon AND central's mon:

  [root@oc0-ceph-1 ceph]# grep 'mon host' dcn0.conf 
  mon host = 192.168.24.8,192.168.24.19,192.168.24.21,192.168.24.18
  [root@oc0-ceph-1 ceph]# grep 'mon host' central.conf 
  mon host = 192.168.24.19,192.168.24.21,192.168.24.18
  [root@oc0-ceph-1 ceph]#

The reason this is happening is because in this task in tripleo_ceph_client/tasks/ceph_ansible.yml

    - name: Get ceph_mon_ip addresses
      set_fact:
        tripleo_ceph_client_mon_ips: "{{ overcloud.get('ceph_mon_node_ips', []) }}"
      vars:
        overcloud: "{{ lookup('file', playbook_dir + '/group_vars/overcloud.json') }}"

overcloud.json on the dcn0 stack contains all four mon host IPs:

    "ceph_mon_node_ips": [
        "192.168.24.8",
        "192.168.24.19",
        "192.168.24.21",
        "192.168.24.18"
    ],

Why? Because when that stack was created the output of `openstack overcloud export --stack control-plane` was passed as input and that file contains this:

"""
parameter_defaults:
  AllNodesExtraMapData:
    # ...
    ceph_mon_node_ips:
    - 192.168.24.19
    - 192.168.24.21
    - 192.168.24.18
    # ...
"""

So given how multistack deployments work they were combined together. Thus, overcloud.json is not the best source for us to build this information. However, the inventory is a source which will have the right information in both the single and multistack case:

$ less tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml
...
DistributedComputeHCI:
  hosts:
    oc0-ceph-1:
      ansible_host: 192.168.24.17
      canonical_hostname: oc0-ceph-1.mydomain.tld
      ctlplane_hostname: oc0-ceph-1.ctlplane.mydomain.tld
      ctlplane_ip: 192.168.24.17
      deploy_server_id: 63c5bc57-8a89-485f-ad73-d8f086eedb12
      internal_api_hostname: oc0-ceph-1.internalapi.mydomain.tld
      internal_api_ip: 192.168.24.17
      storage_hostname: oc0-ceph-1.storage.mydomain.tld
      storage_ip: 192.168.24.17
      storage_mgmt_hostname: oc0-ceph-1.storagemgmt.mydomain.tld
      storage_mgmt_ip: 192.168.24.17
      tenant_hostname: oc0-ceph-1.tenant.mydomain.tld
      tenant_ip: 192.168.24.17
...
ceph_mon:
  children:
    DistributedComputeHCI: {}
...
$

So, I'm going to try an update of this patch to change the "Get ceph_mon_ip addresses" task so it uses the inventory instead. If ceph-ansible is being used, then the inventory of each stack will always have the right mons.

If this task is run with --limit such that a client is excluded, then the {{ tripleo_ceph_client_config_home }} won't be created on those nodes outside of the limit and then this task will still run on all nodes but fail because it couldn't copy the file to a non-existent destination. One way to get around that is to add the following:

 failed_when: false

but then we may not fail when we should (even if they're not using limit). It might be better to have this filter use the inventory but also take into account any magical variables to exclude the limit.

I see the problem here: supposing you're running this playbook w/ --limit, while the task "Ensure /etc/ceph exists on all clients" acts on the host list specified with the --limit option, the loop "push files to the other nodes of cluster" ignores it because it's supposed to  build a list which is the result of mon_client_hosts + ceph_clients.
This makes the task fail because you're trying to push files in a non-existent dest.
I'm not sure which the best approach is here, because on one hand if --limit <hosts> is specified you want to limit the actions on those nodes (leaving untouched all the others), on the other we're not following this approach when files are pushed because we rely on a subset nodes of the inventory (which is in contrast w/ the --limit approach).
Do you think it's worth excluding from the list of targets the nodes that are not specified in the --limit list (if that list exists)?
I'm not sure about the best approach, but I'm going to think more about this case.
Patchset 11 should contain a solution and it's also tested by Molecule.

?: I have some additional questions:

- What is the expected result if MDRAID is not present on the host?

- How could we protect ourselves against this scenario? (or maybe it's something that cannot happen):
  * We have a working instance with a MDRAID NVMe volume attached (4 replicas)
  * Targets #3 and #4 go down
  * We keep writing to targets #1 and #2
  * We stop the instance
  * We attach the volume after a couple of days
  * Now we are only able to attach to targets #3 and #4, which have old data.

- And against this similar scenario? (again, maybe there's already protection at another level)
  * We have a working instance on host #1 with MDRAID NVMe volume as boot volume (4 replicas)
  * Targets #3 and #4 go down
  * Now we do a live migration of the instance to host #2
  * On host #2 we attach the volume but we only have access to target #3 and #4 (old data)
  * Hypervisor believes it's the exact same volume and does the live migration, and when it switches to running it on host #2... Who knows what's actually running.

- What's the impact on multi-attach?

- How does this interact with encryption?  I assume in the same way as multipathed devices.

1. Then the spec should explicitly say that for replicated NVMe volumes the connect_volume method will fail if MDRAID is not present in the system.

2-3. I think these are really concerning scenarios, so we should explicitly mention them in the spec, and in the documentation as a possibility (unlikely, but still).

4. When I talk about multi-attach I don't mean attaching in two host simultaneously as part of a live migration, because in that case Nova orchestrates that only one hypervisor writes to the disk. I'm referring to the possibility of having 2 different instances accessing simultaneously the same block volume, which is the feature called multi-attach in Cinder.  So I believe multi-attach should not be supported for NVMe MDRAID volumes, though I could be wrong.

5. You can see the decryptor code under `os_brick/encryptors`, a good example is `lucks.py`.  And the code calling it will be in somewhere in Nova. It will probably be useful to look at the patch I submitted to the iSCSI connector to fix this issue because I broke encryption when I started returning the real device after refactoring the iSCSI connector: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-brick/+/483069

1. Added to "Other deployer impact" section.

2-3. Mentioning in "Other end user impact" and adding a note about possible remedy.

4. Got it, thank you, yes multi attach is not supported, added a note about it under "Other end user impact"

5. Great pointers, thank you! So yes, expose all devices (bare NVMe and MDRAID) by symlink. Adding it to "Work items" section.

1. It is operator responsibiliy to have necessary linux modules on hosts, this of course will be documented in storage backend docs. If MDRAID replication is required, MDRAID needs to be available. We can also make a check for it and fail if it's missing, but installation should be admin/operator responsibility.

2. As far as I can see there is no way to protect from this (very special scenario) from the consumer / OpenStack side. The storage backend needs to be aware of the divergence, and either sync the old volumes or be aware that they are faulted and not valid candidates as RAID replicas anymore.

3. Same for above. The storage backend (which already handles management of replicated volume replicas metadata, which is something OpenStack is unaware of) is the place to handle this.

Of course, suggestions are welcomed!

4. No impact on multi-attach as far as we saw. We had working demos of live migration. This is something that should be investigated further. Any pointers here would be helpful!

5. Good question, can we please get a pointer to what needs to be handled in the case of encryption? Thank you!

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_kernel/tas.message: nit: How much of a speedup would it be to add 'gather_subset=!all,!any,network' here? (i.e to only update network related facts?

That's actually a pretty good idea. The only thing is that it looks like it's also clearing the original facts which can be presumably used later in the deployment. I'm afraid that it might break a subsequent task.

Here's how I validated:
~~~
ansible -m setup localhost --tree /tmp/facts
cp /tmp/facts/localhost{,.orig}
ip a add 192.168.77.2/24 dev enp0s31f6
ansible -m setup localhost -a 'gather_subset=!all,!any,network' --tree /tmp/facts
diff <(jq -S '.' /tmp/facts/localhost) <(jq -S '.' /tmp/facts/localhost.orig) | less
~~~
Ok, too bad. Thanks for investigating.

tox.ini.message: Can we just change this to py3 so we can stop updating every cycle?

This has been done elsewhere with the idea that the zuul jobs will be what ensures our required runtimes are covered. To make it as easy as possible to try to get developers to actually run tests locally, using py3 makes it a little more flexible that at least some python3 tests are run first. Otherwise you run the risk of someone not having the specific version expected and deciding not to test at all and just leave it up to zuul to do it all.

I guess we could, except that then you'd just be running whatever the system's python3 is, which might not be one of the supported python runtimes.  Maybe that doesn't matter since we'll be running the correct ones in zuul anyway.  I'm not sure.
We do still need this though.

tobiko/tests/scenario/octavia/test_traff.message: Thins 20 should be a multiple of members. We have to make sure it is.

There is some redundancy of info here. The two compared values are printed out by assertEqual method and the word 'failed' is of course redundant too. The actual info added here is that the number of replies is wrong. I would then rephrase it here as below the message with something simple as below:

 assertEqual(self.members_count, len(replies), "wrong number of replies")

Please note the expected value always goes before the actual one.

Same as above, failed world is redundant. The comment and the failure message states different things. Are we actually testing what we expect? This don't look clear to me looking at the code. I wonder this test case is actually broken. We would like all replies are the same number (assuming we are sending a well divisible number of requests). Therefore what I would check is that the values list will be a sequence of n values all with exact one value: example:

  self.assertEqual([requests / members_number] * members_number,
                   actual = list(replies.values(),
                   f"requests unfairly dispatched: {requests}")

The existing logic we have (I didn't change this in my patch) is OK and it was actually taken (copy paste) from Octavia Tempest Plugin as is: 
https://github.com/openstack/octavia-tempest-plugin/blob/efae4470eb91859b6957d9280f0c60de25da54e8/octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/validators.py#L318

Used assertion does exactly what it supposed to do, it check that each member served the same number of requests, for example (Real "replies" taken from tobiko.log):

In [1]: replies={'yxlxlamg\n': 10, 'ocdteuxd\n': 10}

In [2]: len(set(replies.values()))
Out[2]: 1

There is nothing to change here except the redundant Failed string.

In case the test is successful then you are right the code is correct, even if the comment is not telling what the code is doing. But when writing test cases you have to look for failures and help test result consumer to understand what is going wrong. On such case the fix I suggest will give more details about the actual situation by comparing the expected outcome with the actual outcome without assuming we do already know (only by reading the test case code) the number of type of replies is the same as the number of members. I know I am quite pedant, but the fact tempest test case do thing in a different way doesn't mean it is the right one (and often on my experience the quality of tempest test cases is low especially because of the high cost of having them merged). And actually I spotted a bug in case the number of replies is not a multiple of the number of members. Please note that as tobiko resources are shared it is important making sure test case are not assuming things that could change (like the number of members) that actually at some point we should take from a configuration file to check that load balancer is working on heavier conditions (IE: N members as much as we want).

Can't reboot a node from a scenario test case! Please move these tests to a faults test case IE in tobiko/tests/faults/...

Scenario test cases are intended to create and check resources exist. They are execute in parallel and therefore they should never intent any cloud-wise disruption.

Faults test cases are executed sequencially and are actually intended for testing disruptions.
OK, I didn't know that, will be fixed!

web/src/actions/preferences.js.message:
This defines a method that we can dispatch at any time to set a preference.  We could define individual methods for each preference (eg "setAutoReloadPreference"), but I think it may be simpler to just have one generic method with a key/value pair.

We might improve this by making the keys constant.

We could also improve it by just passing a dictionary.  Considering that it's looking like we may only ever dispatch this method when we hit the save button on the dialog, and at that point, we may want to update multiple preferences, that would probably be a good enhancement to make.

web/src/containers/config/Config.jsx.message: This default shouldn't ever be used (because of the resetState below), but it's here just in case.
This should update the state of this dialog to match what's in the redux store whenever the dialog is opened or closed.

-1: These two lines should probably be reversed for clarity, however, the effect is the same regardless due to how setState works.  Pretend that's the case for now.  This dispatches the setPreference method with the current state in this modal (ie, the users new preferences), and then closes the modal.  Of course the close method will then reset the state of this modal to what's in the redux store.

Now, why does this work even though these two lines are in the wrong order (it looks like we reset the state before we update it)?  It's because React doesn't actually update the state of this object until after all of this has completed.  So the state update emitted by setState in handleModalToggle->resetState doesn't take effect until after this method returns.

This maps the 'preferences' key in the redux store to the 'preferences' prop in this dialog.  Here's what this line looks like with metasyntactic variables:

   A: state.B,

That means: this.props.A <- store.B

Our store is defined in store.js and reducers/index.js via the combineReducers call.

web/src/pages/Status.jsx.message: We don't need this anymore since we can get it from the redux store.
This just reverts back to the current production code.

The current production code defaults to having the box checked, so effectively you always end up with the first load happening before the user can uncheck the box.  The new system can end up with a blank page because the user disabled updates.  To compensate, always perform an initial load.
This is called when the redux store is updated.
Again, this makes the redux preferences store available on this.props.preferences.

Update the preference, and persist the new values to disk.

Maybe it's time to solve this old bug:

 https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1708302

So for any openstack container which uses ceph we include a THT patch which mounts the client files genereated by this role in a separate directory just for that container. 

Doing so would let us make this role simpler so we don't have to worry about collisions. I.e. we won't have the following problem:

HCI deployment has /etc/ceph/ populated from ceph-ansible. We don't want this role overwriting in any files in /etc/ceph but at the same time if we want to add a new client option which is applied by this role, then we want that change applied to that client. Rather than introduce complex logic to deal with avoiding collisions in /etc/ceph, we can just use a different directory for clieants than servers which come from different tools. 

So let's keep things simple (and fast) in this role and move that problem out to THT. FWIW cephadm will put the files in a diff directory.

This is secondary to the REST API changes.  You should describe those first.  Something like:

* Add a new optional field, "allow_resize", to the os-retype action.  Possible values will be "on-demand" or "never" (which are the same as the current "migration_policy" field).  If not specified, the default is "never" (unless new_size is specified).

* Add a new optional field, "new_size", to the os-migrate action.  It takes a positive integer argument, the new size of the volume in GB.  This takes precedence over any value specified for "allow_resize".

On that note, I imagine that we only want to allow the new size to be larger (or you risk data loss).  Maybe the way this should work is to call the field "increase_size" and it takes a positive integer value which is the number of GB by which the volume will be increased in size?  Either way works for me as long as it's clear that you can't make a volume smaller with this new functionality.

The  bullet points above should be:

* Add a new optional field, "allow_resize", to the os-retype action.  Possible values will be "on-demand" or "never" (which are the same as the current "migration_policy" field).  If not specified, the default is "never".

* Add a new optional field, "new_size", to the os-migrate action.  It takes a positive integer argument, the new size of the volume in GB.

(I was in a hurry when I wrote them and forgot that allow_resize and new_size are defined for completely different actions, and they can't possibly be specified at the same time.  I still think increase_size might be a good idea, though.)
Maybe name this '--allow-resize'?  (Just needs to be consistent with what you use in the REST API.)
(Don't forget to change this if you decide to go the "increase_size" route above.)
You might as well remind the reader that you already explained why you rejected allowing <1GB size increases in the problem description, above.
It think it will also require a microversion bump.
this should probably all be on one line

There are two ways to go on this:

- new_size - the operator specifies the new size in GB for the volume; request will be rejected if new_size < current size

- increase_size - the operator specifies how many GB to grow the volume (so the final size is current size + increase_size)

What I'm getting at is if you think it's better to ask the operator to specify the final size up front, 'new_size' is a better name.  If you want the value to be an increment, then 'increase_size' is a better name.  What you have now is a mix of the two; I'd like you to pick the one you think best.

I'm going with the second option: 'increase_size - the operator specifies how many GB to grow the volume (so the final size is current size + increase_size)'. Thanks Brian for the clarification, I got confused.
